title: Converting measures of net coverage and number
text: malariasimulation can implement bed net intervention specifying % population distributed bed net (assumed use ) given time points. Simulations frequently involve scenarios constant bednet usage. quantify cost associated given steady-state bednet usage, necessary estimate corresponding number nets need distributed achieve given usage. % individuals protected net time point depends cumulative net distributions occurred duration net retention. netz package additionally allows account observed non-linearities relationship net distributions net access population, based work data Bertozzi-Villa, Amelia, et al. Nature communications 12.1 (2021): 1-12.

title: Converting measures of net coverage and number
text: conversion net usage annual nets distributed per capita occurs following steps: convert net usage net access using observed (country-specific) use rate. definition, net use rate = net usage/net access. convert net access nets per capita using Loess curve fitted observed relationship two across Africa. convert nets per capita annual nets distributed per capita accounting net distributions net loss time. full definition metric relating net coverage, refer original paper (Bertozzi-Villaet al., 2021).

what: Quick example: usage to annual nets distributed conversion for specific countries
title: Converting measures of net coverage and number
text: simple form, 2 steps required: preparing default datasets inform country-specific net variables, converting desired usage annual nets distributed per capita. Note usage can achieved given country depends use rate. target_usage exceeds country-specific use rate, warning printed NA returned annual nets distributed. output shown contains distribution country input usage. Intermediate steps conversion (access crop) also shown. distribution annual, accounts specified net distribution frequency. example, 3 year distribution cycle correspond distributing given output every year, distributing 3 times given output every 3 years. calculate costs distributed nets, user additionally needs convert distribution annual number nets distributed multiplying target population risk. following plot shows non-linear relationship usage distribution (.e. cost) achieve high usages.
code: # First, we specify the coutry iso codes and target usages input <- expand_grid(iso3 = c("AGO", "BEN", "NGA"),                      usage = seq(0.1, 0.9, 0.1))  # We can link these to half life, usage rates and distribution frequencies input <- input %>%   left_join(get_halflife_data(), by = "iso3") %>%   left_join(get_usage_rate_data(), by = "iso3") %>%   mutate(distribution_freq = 365 * 3)  # Next we can follow the conversion chain to move between different bed net measures output <- input %>%   mutate(access = usage_to_access(usage, usage_rate),          npc = access_to_crop(access),          anpcd = crop_to_distribution(npc, distribution_freq = distribution_freq, net_loss_function = net_loss_map, half_life = half_life)) #> Warning in usage_to_access(usage, usage_rate): Target usage(s) cannot be #> achieved with input usage_rates - return NA # Plot relationship between net usage and nets distributed for each country ggplot(output) +   geom_line(aes(     x = usage, y = anpcd,     colour = iso3   )) +   labs(x = "Population net usage", y = "Nets distributed per person-year", colour = "Country") +   theme_classic()

what: Quick example: usage to distribution conversion for a generic setting
title: Converting measures of net coverage and number
text: specific country modelled, possible use functions represent generic average setting accounting observed nets data. following code starts steps previously, now calculates distribution setting net use rate half life corresponding median use rate median half life observed across Africa.
code: # First, we specify the coutry iso codes and target usages input <- expand_grid(usage = seq(0.1, 0.9, 0.1))  # We can link these to aggregate estimates of half life, usage rates and distribution frequencies input <- input %>%   mutate(half_life = median(get_halflife_data()$half_life),          usage_rate = median(get_usage_rate_data()$usage_rate)) %>%   mutate(distribution_freq = 365 * 3)  # Do the conversion output <- input %>%   mutate(access = usage_to_access(usage, usage_rate),          npc = access_to_crop(access),          anpcd = crop_to_distribution(npc, distribution_freq = distribution_freq, net_loss_function = net_loss_map, half_life = half_life)) #> Warning in usage_to_access(usage, usage_rate): Target usage(s) cannot be #> achieved with input usage_rates - return NA

what: Detailed example of further options and assumptions
title: Converting measures of net coverage and number
text: previous examples showed quickest way obtain distribution given usage, users can also: break conversion separate steps vary assumptions relationship crop access, net loss use different (e.g. recent) datasets net metrics relationship access crop derived monthly data latest available year (2020) across African countries, plotted (corresponding Figure 4 paper Bertozzi-Villa et al). three options access_to_crop() function one “loess” loess smooth observed data, second “loess_extrapolate” loess smooth observed data trend extrapolated allow prediction access values outside observed range third, “linear”, linear fit lower (access < 0.5) set observed values. last model simple fit observed data well, use caution.  default assumptions, nets assumed lost according smooth-compact function, depends estimated net half life. proportion nets retained 3-year distribution cycle median retention time / half-life 1.64 years shown .  outputs, target_access calculated target_use/use_rate. Since access proportion, exceed 1. Therefore, target usage higher observed use rate, access = NA.
code: # Read in access vs NPC data: access_npc_data <- get_npc_data()  access <- seq(0, 1, 0.01) npc_loess <- access_to_crop(access, type = "loess") npc_loess_extrapolate <- access_to_crop(access, type = "loess_extrapolate") npc_linear <- access_to_crop(access, type = "linear") model_data <- data.frame(access = rep(access, 3),                          model = rep(c("loess", "loess_extrapolate", "linear"), each = length(npc_loess)),                          npc = c(npc_loess, npc_loess_extrapolate, npc_linear))  # Plot curve ggplot() +   geom_point(data = access_npc_data, aes(x = percapita_nets_mean, y = access_mean), col = "black") +   geom_line(data = model_data, aes(x = npc, y = access, colour = model, lty = model), size = 1.5) +   xlim(0, 1) +   ylim(0, 1) +   labs(x = "Nets per capita", y = "Access (proportion)", colour = "") +   theme_classic() # Calculate proportion of nets retained over a given distribution cycle distribution_cycle_timesteps <- seq(0, 3 * 365, 1) nets_retained <- net_loss_map(   t = distribution_cycle_timesteps,   k = 20,   half_life = 1.64 * 365 ) # k is a fixed rate parameter based on which net half lives were estimated in the paper  # Plot curve ggplot() +   geom_line(aes(x = distribution_cycle_timesteps / 365, y = nets_retained)) +   ylim(0, 1) +   labs(x = "Years", y = "Proportion of bednets retained", colour = "") +   theme_classic()

previous_headings: Detailed example of further options and assumptions
what: Assumptions about the net loss function
title: Converting measures of net coverage and number
text: default option usage_to_distribution() function assumes nets lost according smooth-compact function (net_loss_function = net_loss_map). alternative option assume exponential net loss (net_loss_function = net_loss_exp), corresponds assumption malariasimulation. proportion nets retained time visualised options , 3 year distribution cycle net half life 1.64 years.  effect net loss function relationship net usage distribution shown generic setting.
code: distribution_cycle_timesteps <- seq(0, 3 * 365, 1)  # Calculate proportion of nets retained assuming smooth-compact net loss nets_retained_map <- net_loss_map(   t = distribution_cycle_timesteps,   k = 20,   half_life = 1.64 * 365 ) # k is a fixed rate parameter based on which net half lives were estimated in the paper  # Calculate proportion of nets retained assuming exponential net loss nets_retained_exp <- net_loss_exp(   t = distribution_cycle_timesteps,   half_life = 1.64 * 365 )  # Plot curve ggplot() +   geom_line(aes(     x = distribution_cycle_timesteps / 365, y = nets_retained_map,     colour = "Smooth-compact"   )) +   geom_line(aes(     x = distribution_cycle_timesteps / 365, y = nets_retained_exp,     colour = "Exponential"   )) +   ylim(0, 1) +   labs(x = "Years", y = "Proportion of bednets retained", colour = "") +   theme_classic() # First, we specify some general parameters input <- data.frame(usage = seq(0.1, 0.9, 0.1),                     half_life = median(get_halflife_data()$half_life),                     usage_rate = median(get_usage_rate_data()$usage_rate),                     distribution_freq = 365 * 3)  # Next we can follow the conversion chain to move between different bed net measures output <- input %>%   mutate(access = usage_to_access(usage, usage_rate),          npc = access_to_crop(access),          anpcd_map = crop_to_distribution(npc,                                   distribution_freq = distribution_freq,                                   net_loss_function = net_loss_map,                                   half_life = half_life),          anpcd_exp = crop_to_distribution(npc,                                   distribution_freq = distribution_freq,                                   net_loss_function = net_loss_exp,                                   half_life = 5 * 365)) %>%   select(usage, anpcd_map, anpcd_exp) %>%   pivot_longer(cols = -usage, names_to = "model", values_to = "annual_percapita_nets_distributed", names_prefix = "anpcd_") # Plot relationship between net usage and nets distributed for the 2 net loss assumptions ggplot(data = output, aes(x = usage, y = annual_percapita_nets_distributed, col = model)) +   geom_line() +   labs(x = "Population net usage", y = "Nets distributed per person-year", colour = "Net loss function") +   theme_classic()

title: Converting measures of net coverage and number

title: Estimating population usage from input distribution
text: many cases might set observed population level usage estimates want match . can use non-linear optimiser fit distribution target usages:  Let’s try complex fit, set upper limits annual distribution capture 3-year cycle mass distribution year one followed top-distributions second third year:
code: # Target usage associated time points target <- c(0.45, 0.33, 0.7) target_tt <- c(2, 5, 9) * 365 # Time points at which distribution will occur distribution_tt <- c(1, 4, 8) * 365  # Fit fit <- fit_usage(target_usage = target, target_usage_timesteps = target_tt,                  distribution_timesteps = distribution_tt)  pu <- population_usage(     timesteps = timesteps,     distribution = fit$par,     distribution_timesteps = distribution_tt,     half_life = net_hl)  pd <- data.frame(t = 1:timesteps, usage = pu) pd2 <- data.frame(target = target, target_tt = target_tt)  ggplot() +   geom_line(data = pd, aes(x = t, y = usage)) +   geom_point(dat = pd2, aes(x = target_tt, y = target), col = "cornflowerblue", size = 3) +   ylim(0, 1) +   theme_bw() timesteps <- 12 * 365 # Target usage associated time points target <- seq(0.1, 0.8, length.out = 10) * c(1, 0.8, 0.5, 1, 0.8, 0.5, 1, 0.8, 0.5, 1) target_tt <- (1:10) * 365 # Time points at which distribution will occur distribution_tt <- ((0:9) * 365) + 1 distribution_upper <- c(1, 0.3, 0.3, 1, 0.3, 0.3, 1, 0.3, 0.3, 1)  # Fit fit <- fit_usage(target_usage = target, target_usage_timesteps = target_tt,                  distribution_timesteps = distribution_tt,                  distribution_upper = distribution_upper,                   timesteps = timesteps)  pu <- population_usage(     timesteps = timesteps,     distribution = fit$par,     distribution_timesteps = distribution_tt,     half_life = net_hl)  pd <- data.frame(t = 1:timesteps, usage = pu) pd2 <- data.frame(target = target, target_tt = target_tt)  ggplot() +   geom_line(data = pd, aes(x = t, y = usage)) +   geom_point(dat = pd2, aes(x = target_tt, y = target), col = "cornflowerblue", size = 3) +   ylim(0, 1) +   theme_bw()

code: @Manual{,   title = {netz: All Things Bed Nets},   author = {Pete Winskill and Nora Schmit and Ines Gerard-Ursin},   year = {2022},   note = {R package version 0.1.3}, }

title: All Things Bed Nets
text: Netz help setup bed nets malariasimulation. Much functionality within package based excellent bed net model Bertozzi-Villa, Amelia, et al. Nature communications 12.1 (2021): 1-12, please check make sure cite appropriately use package. One key features netz package help conversions different metrics net coverage net numbers. defined throughout : Usage: proportion population net slept . Access: proportion population live household sleep bed net. Crop: number nets population. Always expressed nets per capita. Distribution: number nets distributed. Always expressed nets per capita per year. Broadly, distribution relate cost programme usage impact. metrics modelled within malariasimulation. therefore need careful model inputs match desired target usage specifying bed nets. schematic help understanding elements relate one another
